snippet.textDisplay: No u don't have to file a return if u are on SS,SSI,or SS DISABILITY if your yearly income is low.i haven't filed taxes since 2012 because my only income is less than $14,000 a yr,social security.the government says i do not need to file each year if my income is solely SS and poverty level.the stimulus check will be mailed or deposited going by the info the goverment already has on you.(mailing address,direct deposit to your bank account)
snippet.textOriginal: No u don't have to file a return if u are on SS,SSI,or SS DISABILITY if your yearly income is low.i haven't filed taxes since 2012 because my only income is less than $14,000 a yr,social security.the government says i do not need to file each year if my income is solely SS and poverty level.the stimulus check will be mailed or deposited going by the info the goverment already has on you.(mailing address,direct deposit to your bank account)

snippet.textDisplay: The one thing that has not been expressed is what about people who have ZERO income because either they don't have a job in order to file a tax return because they are homeless or people who have been fighting Social Security to get Social Security disability benefits and they have been denied over and over and over. Like me, I have been considered disabled by a "medical expert" and Occupational therapist at a appeal hearing in 2018 but was denied by a judge. Then I filed again and was denied again and that was after adding in more current medical conditions and depression issues. So because of that I have been fighting Social Security for ten years. And I have been getting increasingly  worse. Where does that leave people who are in the same type of situation I am in? Anyone?

snippet.textDisplay: If we receive our SS checks thru direct deposit, will they not use that address? I was widowed in ‘18 and moved in ‘19. snippet.textDisplay:
SSA (Social Security recipients) not required to file Income Tax BUT would only get $1200 per SSA recipient. If household has only one SSA recipient but two adults (other spouse not on SSA), household would only get $1200 because IRS doesn't know about other individual. If it's just you in "household," don't sweat it. If both of you get SSA don't sweat it. If neither of those scenarios fit you, FILE. It's quick, easy, free. ... ... ...FROM WEBSITE -- "Q: I am not typically required to file a tax return. Can I still receive my payment?
A: Yes. The IRS will use the information on the Form SSA-1099 or Form RRB-1099 to generate Economic Impact Payments to recipients of benefits reflected in the Form SSA-1099 or Form RRB-1099 who are not required to file a tax return and did not file a return for 2018 or 2019. This includes senior citizens, Social Security recipients and railroad retirees who are not otherwise required to file a tax return.
...Since the IRS would not have information regarding any dependents for these people, each person would receive $1,200 per person, without the additional amount for any dependents at this time." -- https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/economic-impact-payments-what-you-need-to-know
snippet.textOriginal:
SSA (Social Security recipients) not required to file Income Tax BUT would only get $1200 per SSA recipient. If household has only one SSA recipient but two adults (other spouse not on SSA), household would only get $1200 because IRS doesn't know about other individual. If it's just you in "household," don't sweat it. If both of you get SSA don't sweat it. If neither of those scenarios fit you, FILE. It's quick, easy, free. ... ... ...FROM WEBSITE -- "Q: I am not typically required to file a tax return. Can I still receive my payment?
A: Yes. The IRS will use the information on the Form SSA-1099 or Form RRB-1099 to generate Economic Impact Payments to recipients of benefits reflected in the Form SSA-1099 or Form RRB-1099 who are not required to file a tax return and did not file a return for 2018 or 2019. This includes senior citizens, Social Security recipients and railroad retirees who are not otherwise required to file a tax return.
...Since the IRS would not have information regarding any dependents for these people, each person would receive $1,200 per person, without the additional amount for any dependents at this time." -- https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/economic-impact-payments-what-you-need-to-know

snippet.textDisplay:
IMPORTANT MESSAGE: Okay....so here is a new, specific and accurate update regarding the Treasury Departments change about people receiving "Social Security" not having to take any action to receive their stimulus check, as it applies to SSI, Veterans Affairs, etc. Go to www.cbpp.gov and read the article/BLOG by Chuck Marr, dated April 2, 2020 at 3 PM. The "Center on Budget and Policy Priorities" makes it clear in their article (second paragraph) that "Recipients of SSI and Veterans Affairs (VA) pension benefits who don't file returns and don't receive Social Security retirement or disability benefits aren't covered by Treasury's decision yesterday to provide payments automatically to Social Security beneficiaries who don't file." This is what I was worried about because when the Treasury Department came out with that update yesterday they just said Social Security and never mentioned specifics, such as SSI, Veterans Affairs, etc., which is what they would do if it applied to those groups, as they differ in many ways. So at this point it seems that there are people and groups out there that are fighting for those on SSI and the like to have them included in not having to file a return or a "simple return" in order to receive the stimulus check, but right now that decision is in limbo and a decision should be made in the near future to determine what steps, if any, those on SSI and the like may have to take to receive their stimulus check. If you read the entire article you will get the idea that they are still trying to get this worked out and are trying to make it so that those specific people won't have to take any action and will just receive their checks by direct deposit or by mail. I don't really understand what the issue is. The SSA has all of the information for those on SSI, just like those receiving SSDI, and they could just as easily access their information from the SSA to determine qualification and to provide the stimulus checks. I guess we will have to wait a little while to see what they decide to do. I just wanted for everyone under these circumstances to know the truth because so many people have been spreading false and inaccurate information in these posts. Please go to the site and read the entire article. Hopefully this will all get worked out quickly and effectively !
Apologies.... previously I provided the above site using .org instead of .gov and I have corrected that mistake. You can now access the BLOG at www.cbpp.gov
snippet.textOriginal:
IMPORTANT MESSAGE: Okay....so here is a new,  specific and accurate update regarding the Treasury Departments change about people receiving "Social Security" not having to take any action to receive their stimulus check, as it applies to SSI, Veterans Affairs, etc. Go to www.cbpp.gov and read the article/BLOG by Chuck Marr, dated April 2, 2020 at 3 PM. The "Center on Budget and Policy Priorities" makes it clear in their article (second paragraph) that "Recipients of SSI and Veterans Affairs (VA) pension benefits who don't file returns and don't receive Social Security retirement or disability benefits aren't covered by Treasury's decision yesterday to provide payments automatically to Social Security beneficiaries who don't file." This is what I was worried about because when the Treasury Department came out with that update yesterday they just said Social Security and never mentioned specifics, such as SSI, Veterans Affairs, etc., which is what they would do if it applied to those groups, as they differ in many ways. So at this point it seems that there are people and groups out there that are fighting for those on SSI and the like to have them included in not having to file a return or a "simple return" in order to receive the stimulus check, but right now that decision is in limbo and a decision should be made in the near future to determine what steps, if any, those on SSI and the like may have to take to receive their stimulus check. If you read the entire article you will get the idea that they are still trying to get this worked out and are trying to make it so that those specific people won't have to take any action and will just receive their checks by direct deposit or by mail. I don't really understand what the issue is. The SSA has all of the information for those on SSI, just like those receiving SSDI, and they could just as easily access their information from the SSA to determine qualification and to provide the stimulus checks. I guess we will have to wait a little while to see what they decide to do. I just wanted for everyone under these circumstances to know the truth because so many people have been spreading false and inaccurate information in these posts. Please go to the site and read the entire article. Hopefully this will all get worked out quickly and effectively ! 
Apologies.... previously I provided the above site using .org instead of .gov and I have corrected that mistake. You can now access the BLOG at www.cbpp.gov

snippet.textDisplay:
I filed both 2018 and 2019 tax returns. That being said, the stimulus check(s) will be direct deposited because that's how I directed my refund(s). I'm also on Social Security (Retirement). All I've read about those on Social Security will receive the check, my
Social Security check is also direct deposited so I reasonable believe the Stimulus check will be direct deposited as well. Now, a while back I read that you need not file a tax return to qualify, however, those who did not file, Adults will receive a reduced check of $600. 1) I know thing can AND DO change on a dime 2) In this video, this is the first time I heard about going to any web portal to file for your stimulus check - GREAT CAUTION IS ADVISED HERE - if it were me, I WOULD NOT relinquish any information via this media UNLESS it was a dot gov (.gov) web site and your information is protected. 3). Last but not least - - I know there are many helpful individuals, BUT PLEASE, do not base your actions on ANY so-called instructional youtube video. The scammers are out in full force. Trust me, the IRS and/or the Federal government know exactly who you are. If you believe for some reason you might be missed, YOU contact THEM. Be careful, Be safe, Be well.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: According to the IRS website anyone receiving Social Security for retirement, or Social Security Disability Insurance (SSDI) or Supplemental Security Income (SSI) will get the 2020 Stimulus check and they will NOT have file any taxes to get it, it will either be direct deposited or mailed to you.
snippet.textOriginal: According to the IRS website anyone receiving Social Security for retirement, or Social Security Disability Insurance (SSDI) or Supplemental Security Income (SSI) will get the 2020 Stimulus check and they will NOT have file any taxes to get it, it will either be direct deposited or mailed to you.

snippet.textDisplay: NOT TRUE use the Treasury Dept's Website for the truth. go too (home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sm967) posted April 1st. Last update your post because you are just creating mass confusion to people who already have enough Stress to deal with.

snippet.textDisplay: Treasury says you don't have to file. Wherever your SS checks go your stimulus check will go.
snippet.textOriginal: Treasury says you don't have to file. Wherever your SS checks go your stimulus check will go.

snippet.textDisplay:
Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin Wednesday announced that Social Security recipients would not have to file tax returns in order to receive coronavirus stimulus payments.


The reversal comes after complaints from lawmakers that an IRS plan to require seniors to file simplified returns would place an undue burden on them amid widespread shutdowns and social distancing guidelines implemented in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak.

https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/01/social-security-recipients-coronavirus-stimulus-160757
snippet.textOriginal:
Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin Wednesday announced that Social Security recipients would not have to file tax returns in order to receive coronavirus stimulus payments.


The reversal comes after complaints from lawmakers that an IRS plan to require seniors to file simplified returns would place an undue burden on them amid widespread shutdowns and social distancing guidelines implemented in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak.

https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/01/social-security-recipients-coronavirus-stimulus-160757
